awd_titl_txt: Building Assessment Items and Instructional Tasks to Build Intercommunity Capacity to Develop Teachers' Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. The infrastructure to improve mathematics education in the US requires building human resources in mathematics and mathematics education into a professional community that can respond to the critical needs in the field. This project seeks to build a professional community with shared understanding of the specialized content knowledge (SCK) - the special forms and ways of reasoning about mathematical knowledge used in teaching (MKT). This community will help increase the capacity for further research and development on teachers' SCK in mathematics, which has been shown to relate to student achievement.  Building on the professional community's shared knowledge, the project will also work to collaboratively develop an item bank of MKT/SCK items and tasks using the platform developed by the Illustrative Mathematics group for similar task and item development for K-12 students. Better measures, with a larger item bank, will help support both the learning and assessment of teachers' MKT/SCK. 

Based on theories of communities of practice, this project will bring together mathematicians and mathematics educators to build a professional community with a shared understanding of the SCK in mathematics through engaging in efforts to develop items to measure SCK and the development of a task bank. Based on the "item camps" they engaged with to develop prior measures, the project will host twelve 4-day camps with varying themes for pairs of faculty and teachers or graduate students, ensuring a mix of mathematicians and educators. This work will lead to a certification for MKT/SCK. They will also develop approximately 60 items and have a mechanism for the future review and publishing of items. Using case-study methodologies, the project will study the development of these partnerships and the professional communities within and across the camps.

por.por_cntn:
This project helped mathematics teacher educators develop understanding of specialized mathematical knowledge for teaching oriented to the work that teachers must do as they help students learn the subject.  For example, teachers formulate questions to probe students’ thinking, analyze students’ work, and develop and adapt math problems for use in instruction. Teachers must be attentive to the integrity of the discipline but also oriented to the thinking of others. This is different from how other professionals, including mathematicians, need to know mathematics. Mathematicians apply mathematical tools and prove new ideas, pursue generalization and abstraction. In contrast, teachers focus on seeking ways to build connections to learners. Mathematical knowledge for teaching is different to teach than disciplinary mathematics.  Learning to focus on it requires significant reorientation and support for those who are trained in formal mathematics.

Toward this end, the project built a series of workshops for mathematics teacher educators — mathematicians, teacher educators, professional developers, lead teachers, and others who support teachers’ mathematics learning. Based on extensive research on mathematical knowledge for teaching, the project engaged participants in developing tasks to build such knowledge. As they worked, they learned how a mathematical idea or process could be shaped toward its use in teaching. The project also focused on the demands of teaching mathematics with equity in mind.

Project staff conducted 15 multi-day workshops, enrolling more than 200 participants from across the U.S.. Many attended multiple workshops. Participants reported that the workshops informed their teaching, interactions with colleagues, research, and the programs and policies they oversee.

A subset of workshops worked with equity scholars to analyze the mathematical demands of equitable teaching.  Project staff collaborated with senior scholars (~3) who helped us support a cadre of junior faculty (~13) and their graduate students (~10) over several years. Activities expanded these scholars’ networks, supported their teaching and writing, and fostered independent initiatives. The junior faculty members now have tenure, and the graduate students are junior faculty or other equity-focused professionals. Support for these early career scholars, associated with roughly 30 universities, is key to growing capacity in the field.

Another significant impact comes from presentations about this work. With approximately 100 presentations, the project has communicated core ideas and insights to mathematicians, teacher educators, coaches, teachers, mathematics supervisors, curriculum specialists, assessment developers, researchers, policymakers, community groups, and the general public. Eighteen papers and one book have reported on associated research efforts.

In addition to providing professional development for mathematics teacher educators, a secondary aim was to contribute understanding of both the mathematical demands of attending to equity and the challenges of learning about and teaching mathematical knowledge for teaching. First, the project developed tasks that address mathematical knowledge for equitable teaching. Many past tools for measuring mathematical knowledge for teaching have suffered from bias and lacked specificity to the demands of equitable teaching. The project produced compelling examples, as well as guidance for their development (e.g., design heuristics, prototypes, task specifications, task criteria, review criteria, review protocols, and reviewer training guidelines). The project articulated mathematical demands of equitable teaching, elaborated the practice of assigning competence, and identified teacher discretion as fundamental in  reproducing or disrupting patterns of inequity. 

A second contribution is the development of approaches for using artifacts of teaching and teacher education to analyze practice and to support professionals’ learning. Using video records of cases of mathematics teaching, along with mathematical tasks and student work, the project has challenged the persistent divide between theory and practice, between aspirations and classroom realities. This approach has also shown how collective deliberation can strengthen work to advance equity and improve communication across differences in perspective and experience.

A final contribution was to explore how mathematics teacher educators think about content knowledge for teaching and how this might matter for developing their practice. Findings were that some think about mathematical knowledge for teaching as an independent resource to be taught and learned in isolation from teaching, while others think about it as contextualized in practice.  Some connected mathematical knowledge to teaching and to equity, while others treated these as unconnected. These results helped to show why, despite perceived agreement, change has been nominal. This line of work has provided insights for strengthening efforts to develop mathematics teacher educators and improve teachers’ mathematics education.
